channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Iran’s Supreme Leader Says Sanctions Must Lift When Nuclear Deal Is Signed
item.description: Iran’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, declared on Thursday that all sanctions would have to be lifted on the day any deal is signed and that military sites would be strictly off limits to foreign inspectors.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK and DAVID E. SANGER

item.title: Jean-Claude Turcotte, Former Archbishop of Montreal, Dies at 78
item.description: Cardinal Turcotte drew headlines in 2008 when he returned his Order of Canada medal to protest the decision to bestow the honor on an abortion doctor.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.media:description: Cardinal Jean-Claude Turcotte celebrating Mass at the Olympic Stadium in Montreal to celebrate the elevation of Brother André in 2010.

item.title: Fighting and Deprivation Worsen in Yemen
item.description: A Houthi advance in eastern Yemen, despite Saudi aerial assaults, came as new signs emerged that all commercial ships were avoiding the country.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:description: Saudi forces on Thursday had tanks deployed on their side of the border between Saudi Arabia and Yemen.

item.title: State Department Review of Cuba’s Status on Terrorism List Is Complete, Obama Says
item.description: President Obama, in Jamaica at a gathering of Caribbean leaders, said he had not yet received a final recommendation on whether Cuba should be removed from the list of nations that sponsor terrorism.
item.dc:creator: JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS
item.media:description: President Obama after a meeting in Kingston, Jamaica on Thursday with Prime Minister Portia Simpson-Miller.

item.title: Biden Cites Progress in Iraq’s War With ISIS
item.description: In a speech, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. said Iraq had halted the momentum of Islamic State fighters with help from the United States and regional allies.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL D. SHEAR
item.media:description: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. speaking at the National Defense University in Washington on Thursday.

item.title: French Broadcaster TV5 Monde Recovers After Hacking
item.description: A cyberattack by hackers claiming to support the Islamic State militant group had shut down transmission and wrested control of online accounts.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN and ALISSA J. RUBIN
item.media:description: The website of the French television broadcaster TV5 Monde on Wednesday. The network regained control of its social media accounts on Thursday, and its website was back online.

item.title: As Bombings Add Up, Cyprus Soccer Hits a New Low
item.description: Bombs targeted at referees’ cars, corruption and club bankruptcies combine to create a grim picture of professional soccer in Cyprus.
item.dc:creator: SAM BORDEN
item.media:description: Gustavo Manduca celebrated after scoring a penalty kick for Apoel against Ajax during a Champions League match. Even Apoel, one of the most successful clubs in Cyprus, has had financial problems.

item.title: Taliban Attack in Northern Afghanistan Leaves at Least 10 Dead
item.description: In a city known as a model of stability, the Taliban attacked a local prosecutor’s office where militants were disguised as Afghan security personnel.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Joking About Mao Lands Chinese TV Host in Hot Water
item.description: Tipsy jibes by the Chinese television celebrity Bi Fujian caught on video have been enough to inspire tirades from the state media and imperil Mr. Bi’s career.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Russian Consumers Reflect the Pinch of Economic Sanctions
item.description: After years of insatiability, consumers are curbing their spending, leaving shopping centers and other retail space with high vacancies.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Moscow's Avia Park mall, Europe's largest, has suffered from dwindling crowds and fewer retailers since sanctions over the Ukraine conflict took effect and oil prices fell.

item.title: Amid Political Confrontations in Bangladesh, a Search for a Missing Opposition Official
item.description: Family members and Bangladesh Nationalist Party leaders say they are certain security forces are responsible for the disappearance of Salahuddin Ahmed.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY
item.media:credit: Munir Uz Zaman/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Khaleda Zia, the Bangladeshi opposition leader, before her court appearance on Sunday in Dhaka.

item.title: Kenya Struggles Over Best Response to University Attack
item.description: Opposition leaders demanded that troops be pulled from Somalia and accused the president of trying to emasculate the judiciary by flouting a court order and calling up 10,000 police recruits.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN
item.media:description: People waited at a mortuary in Nairobi, Kenya, on Wednesday to view the bodies of relatives killed in last week’s terrorist attack.

item.title: News Analysis: Ahead of World War II Anniversary, Questions Linger Over Stance of Japan’s Premier
item.description: While Prime Minister Shinzo Abe has expressed remorse for the war, suspicions that he remains an unrepentant revisionist have kept Japan from a more assertive regional role.
item.dc:creator: MARTIN FACKLER
item.media:description: Emperor Akihito of Japan and Empress Michiko on Thursday at a memorial for the 1,600 Americans who died during World War II on Peleliu Island, Palau.

item.title: U.N. Rights Chief Criticizes Malaysian Antiterror Measure
item.description: The United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights warned against the government’s move to restore powers of indefinite detention without trial.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: Scientists Question Environmental Impact of China’s Winter Olympics Bid
item.description: According to Bejing’s bid, the impact from the Games would be “eco-friendly.” But conservationists say that holding the Games in a water-stressed environment would be devastating.
item.dc:creator: IAN JOHNSON
item.media:credit: Sim Chi Yin for The New York Times
item.media:description: A ski resort near Zhangjiakou, China, that will be used as a venue for some events if China holds the 2022 Winter Olympics. Artificial snow makes up for a shortfall of the real thing.

item.title: China Says Construction in Contested Waters Is for Maritime Purposes
item.description: A Foreign Ministry spokeswoman defended the island-building work in the South China Sea, noting it would help ships in the event of typhoons.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG
item.media:credit: Center for Strategic and International Studies, via Digital Globe
item.media:description: A satellite image from March 17 shows work on an emerging artificial island at Mischief Reef in the South China Sea.

item.title: Kerry Says U.S. Knew of Iran’s Military Aid to Houthi Rebels
item.description: In an interview on Wednesday with “PBS NewsHour,” Secretary of State John Kerry said Washington was “not going to stand by while the region is destabilized.”
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry delivering remarks to the news media in Lausanne, Switzerland, on April 2.

item.title: U.S. Defense Chief Arrives in South Korea Amid News of North’s Missile Launches
item.description: At confirmed reports that Pyongyang had fired two short-range missiles off its coast, Ashton B. Carter said, “If it was a welcome message to me, I’m flattered.”
item.dc:creator: HELENE COOPER
item.media:description: Defense Secretary Ashton B. Carter, right, embraced Gen. Curtis Scaparrotti upon Mr. Carter’s arrival on Thursday at Osan Air Base, South Korea.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: In China, a Climate of Mistrust in Medicine
item.description: An overburdened and underfinanced system has contributed to treatment often shaped by commercial rather than medical concerns.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: People seeking medical care line up at a hospital in Shanghai.

item.title: Chile Joins Other Latin American Nations Shaken by Scandal
item.description: Corruption cases are raising doubts about a country that has been a darling of global finance institutions and exposing figures across the ideological spectrum to scorn.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO
item.media:credit: Jose Manuel De La Maza/Chilean President's Office
item.media:description: President Michelle Bachelet of Chile presented a bill last month that would create a women's ministry.
